Navigate to other release versions of Doxee Platform Template Designer

[6.6](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/template-designer-6-6)

[6.7](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/template-designer-6-7)

Views are used to display and/or modify template components and also to give access to other useful features while working with Doxee Template Designer.

## Dependencies
The Dependencies view allows determining which components (template parts, styles, page masters, variables) are used in which template.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 47. Dependencies*

The example above shows an overview of all template parts and templates, which use the template part "header". In this case, it is only referenced once, in the template changedata.itx.

The corresponding file can be opened by double clicking it.

### Configuration
To start the analysis the function must be configured through Edit &gt; Preferences &gt; Dependencies (see [Dependencies](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-actions-1#dependencies)).

Clicking the Settings icon in the Dependencies View performs the same action.

### Utilisation
**![](data:image/png;base64,)**

*Figure 48. Selecting the analysis reference*

Click on the *Search Dependencies *symbol in the top right corner of the Dependencies view to select the element, of which the references in other Infinica files should be found.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 49. Selecting the analysis directory*

Choose an Index and select the desired analysis directory, which was previously configured (see [Dependencies](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-actions-1#dependencies)). All the Infinica resources (*.itx) are listed below and the desired element for the analysis can be selected, after which the list with the dependencies will be displayed.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 50. List with dependencies*

## Search &amp; Replace
The view Search &amp; Replace allows searching and replacing strings within an opened file.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 51. Search &amp; Replace View*

By either selecting the Text or Attributes option it is possible to search within the text content or within attributes. Checking the Regular Expression option enables the use of regular expressions as search strings.

## Outline
The Outline View provides highly precise navigation and selection in form of a tree representation. It displays the content and structure of the currently opened Infinica Template. A consistent colour concept throughout Doxee Template Designer accelerates navigating in the Outline View as well.

Dynamic elements (e.g. Dynamic Value, Variable, etc.) use a blue colour scheme for their icons and their labels. Logical Elements (i.e. Repeat, Condition and Branches) use an orange colour scheme.

The content of the corresponding elements, such as text or the content of dynamic elements (i.e. the contained XPath-expressions), is displayed next to the element icon and name.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 52. Outline View*

### Structure
The Outline view displays the elements of the document as explained in [Document Structure](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-document-structure). The root elements are:

- Namespaces

- Scripts

- Global Variables

- Decimal Formats

- Page masters

- Bookmarks

- Page sequences: This is the part that has a graphical representation and is also available in the graphical editor (see [Editor](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-editor-1)).

Page sequence

Page content

- Template Parts

- External Resources

- Data Inputs

- Schemas

- Style Packages

- Insertion Point States

- Output Configurations

Any root element can be displayed in a separate view for easier navigation by right-clicking it and choosing *Open in separate view *from the context menu. Once it appears as separate view, the element disappears from the general Outline view. It re-appears as soon as the extra view is closed.

By default, Data Inputs and Style Packages are displayed in separate views.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Show Template Part Contents
The function *show template part contents *shows the content of the referenced template parts in the Outline View. The content cannot be edited with the exception to activate or fix condition branches for previews.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Show ID
Assuming a template with a complex structure it makes sense to set an ID to elements in order to refer to them, as well as to label them. An ID is set using the context menu entry *Set ID*.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 53. Outline View &gt; Set ID*

The ![](data:image/png;base64,) show ID icon on top right of the Outline View allows showing or hiding IDs in the labels of the elements in the *Outline View*.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Expand all
The function expand all expands all elements in the *Outline *view.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Collapse all
The function collapse all collapses all elements in the *Outline *view.

### Expand or collapse certain element types
The option *Expand all: &lt;element type&gt; *or rather *Collapse all: &lt;element type&gt; *in the context menu of an element expands or collapses all elements of one type which are found in the current template.

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) Properties
The *Properties *view allows setting and manipulating properties of all elements. There are graphical property tabs for most elements which give access to commonly used properties and an *Advanced Property *tab which holds all available properties for selected elements in tabular form.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Fonts
The *Fonts *tab of the *Properties *view allows setting font properties graphically. Further font related properties can be set via *Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Fonts*. Colour settings can be made in the Color: Font and Color: Background fields. The fields *Font *and *Font size *allow font settings. Setting the font size is possible through the offered choices in the combo box or by typing own values.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 54. Views &gt; Properties &gt; Fonts*

### ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAA8AAAAPCAYAAAA71pVKAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAASElEQVQokWN0cHD4z0AmYGFgYGDYv38/yRodHR0ZmAgpwAfwaibkoqFuM0whMr1//36s4nDg4ODwHxcgJDcI/Dy0bGakJFcBANCdUXcBKK2IAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) Border
The Border tab of the Properties View allows setting borders to ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAARUlEQVQ4jWN0cHD4z4ADHDhwgHHOvPk45RkYGBgYcBmAz2BkwEJIASEXEDQgJSmRcQi4AF+AEYwFSgHheKY1GHXBYHABANEoImfx0KvuAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) Blocks, ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAIAAACQkWg2AAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAPElEQVQoke2OwREAEBDElhZRSXo8uloVMO4vr7wyKYAyVEmtj9bHo9RUXlLJLgmIuWIuwLbtu/ylv3RgA68MpKHw6K5vAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) Tables (and their sub elements) and ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAATUlEQVQ4jc1SQQoAMAiysYf59H7W7q0gaLA8WolZwG9IRJK0iFfVq391HQwQyPatgKS1HeyIjNLO8M6Bz8K7yOoDztgVSP++OisdAQA4hJ8XGSMcbfoAAAAASUVORK5CYII=) Containers.

**Attribute**

**Description**

*style*

The border style can be selected here.

*color*

The border colour can be set using the elements Color and width section.

*width*

The border width can be chosen with the combo box in the Color and width section.

It is either possible to use the predefined widths for the borders or to enter a numeric value using a unit, e.g. pt. or mm. Borders to either side of the selected element can be set/reset using the buttons in the section *Line Arrangement *or use the section *User-defined *to define the desired sides there.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 55. Properties &gt; Border*

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Distances
The Distances tab of the Properties View allows setting margins and paddings. As defined in the XSL-FO standard the margin properties are used to define outer distances of an element in contrast to padding defining inner distances. The Advanced Properties offer further distance and formatting properties space and indent as well as their subsets. Values can be set using metric units (i.e. mm and cm) and pt.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 56. Properties &gt; Distances*

The XSL specification defines the distance properties as displayed below.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 57. Definition of distance properties*

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Images
When selecting an inserted *Image *element it is possible to manipulate its properties using the *Image *tab of the *Properties view*.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 58. Properties &gt; Image*

**Attribute**

**Description**

*Source*

Defines the image source.

*Width / Height*

Defines the desired width / height of the image in the output document.

*Scale Option*

Is used to define which side to use for *uniform scaling*. In order to change scaling to *non-uniform scaling *click the chain icon aside the dimension fields *Width *and *Height *or change *Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Area- Dimension &gt; scaling *to non-uniform. The scale option can also be changed using *Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Area-Dimension &gt; scaling-option*.

### ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAOCAYAAAAmL5yKAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAALklEQVQokWNgYGD4zwAB/5EwAzL9//9/XPL/mRgoBKMGjBpAOwOgSXcAXUAKAADbyhEKdDavFgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==) Barcode
Having a *Barcode *element selected it is possible to manipulate its properties using the Barcode tab of the Properties view. A barcode always needs to have an XPath expression and a type, otherwise the template cannot be rendered. From currently 38 different types of barcodes (e.g. QR-code, datamatrix, EAN), the desired one has to be selected. Also there are two different barcode generators available (Barcode4j and Aspose) which can be selected in *Advanced &gt; Barcode &gt; barcode-generator*.

> Important

The values of some barcode types have to follow certain, barcode dependent rules, otherwise they cannot be rendered correctly. E.g. the barcode type *binary *can only hold *Zeros *and *Ones*.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 59. Properties &gt; Barcode*

For further information how to insert and use a barcode see chapter ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAN0lEQVQ4je3MoQ3AMBADwEsn8+jeLCUB4SUFb2JZsm4l2W1Xkg1tF5wd9Gr3Fx4fM8AAA/wFeAGjNg/flvjZEAAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==) [Barcode](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-elements-1#barcode).

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Dynamic Value
The *Dynamic Values *tab of the *Properties *view allows managing the properties of *Dynamic Values *(see chapter ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAsAAAAICAIAAACgWpLfAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAaUlEQVQYlX2Ouw3AIAxELyid12AYBmEAOlaAjnEYhjGOmhRWFOejvOrkd5JvI5lSGmPgTggh5wzAiUhrzXv/qQE4AI+S1QCwTkjGGEspy0DS4RcR2TXNOXWvTrZfnNV66r3XWq/GQ79LB+kdT1Flu1PAAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) [Marker](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-elements-1#marker)) graphically.

In the input field *Expression *the source path or XPath expression can be entered. By choosing a type of dynamic data it is possible to assign formatting patterns. A formatting pattern represents a function or transformation applied to the value of an XPath function. Each of the options corresponds to an XPath function ([http://www.w3.org/2005/xpath-functions/](http://www.w3.org/2005/xpath-functions/)).

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 60. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value*

The option *Number *represents the XPath function *format-number*. The field *Pattern *represents the *$picture *string of the XPath function. # is used to define optional digits and 0 is used to define mandatory digits. A valid pattern could be ###.##0,00. The input field Format is used to specify Decimal Formats to use. The default *Decimal Format *does not need a name. Thus if no value is entered the default *Decimal Format *is used.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 61. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: number*

*Number as word *outputs a numeric value from the XML data source as word. This is mainly used for monetary amounts. The field *Decimal digits *is used to specify the number of decimal places to be output. The field accepts numeric input. The field *Language *currently accepts the values de, de-BANK and en as input which behave as described in the following table.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 62. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: number as word*

**Number as word language**

**Example**

en

21 &gt; twentyone 1234 &gt; onethousandtwohundredthirtyfour

de

21 &gt; einundzwanzig 1234 &gt; eintausendzweihundertvierunddreiig

de-BANK

21 &gt; zwanzigeins 1234 &gt; eintausendzweihundertdreiigvier

The option *Date *represents the XPath function *format-date*. The input field *Pattern *represents the *$picture *string of the XPath function. The function requires a correctly formatted date as input, i.e. 2016-12-24. Applicable values are D for the *days *of the date object, M for the *months *of the date object and Y for the *years *of the date object. Each of them to be used embraced by square brackets. Between the brackets any symbol may be placed. By just using D, M or Y the value is given out as it is. Using 0 the number of mandatory places can be defined e.g. display a leading zero. In order to output a part of the date (e.g. the days) as ordinal number a small o digit is to be added. In addition to specifying a language this results in the ordinal sign being added, e.g. the th for 5th in case of English language. To give out the month as text add N to the M tag. A valid pattern could be [D0o] [MNn] [Y], for instance. All further fields match the fields in the XPath function.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 63. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: date*

The option Time represents the XPath function *format-time*. The input field *Pattern *represents the *$picture *string of the XPath function. All further fields match the fields in the XPath function.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 64. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: time*

The option *Date/time *represents the XPath function *format-dateTime*. The function requires a correctly formatted *dateTime *as input. The input field *Pattern *represents the *$picture *string of the XPath function. All further fields match the fields in the XPath function.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 65. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: date/time*

Using the option String the Dynamic Value is casted to type text in the XSLT output.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 66. Properties &gt; Dynamic Value &gt; Formatting: text*

### ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAASklEQVQ4jWNgoBAwMjAwMDg4OPxHFjxw4AAjsQYwwRj79+9n2L9/P8kuYCKsBD9ggTEcHR1RJNC9hQM4UOqA0UAcDUQGBobBEIgA65kh0AOPstsAAAAASUVORK5CYII=) List
In order to assign style types for *List *elements various types of list styles can be chosen in the List tab of the *Properties View*. The following list style types are currently available:

- Disc

- Circle

- Square

- Numeric

- Numeric with leading zero

- Lower case Roman numbers

- Upper case Roman numbers

- Lower case alphabetic

- Upper case alphabetic

The input fields *Prefix *and *Suffix *allow defining arbitrary values to add either before or to append to the list specific characters. This can also be used to define custom list characters, such as a lozenge ().

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 67. Properties &gt; List*

All list properties can also be set via *Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Bullets And Numbering &gt; *. *Using *Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Bullets And Numbering &gt; list-start-value *it is possible to set the start value of a list item in case a numbered *List *is chosen.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 68. Properties &gt; Advanced &gt; Bullets and Numbering*

### ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAQAAAAPCAYAAADDNm69AAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAWklEQVQImWP8OJlhAgMDgwEDBFxggXLsoQIMTAxogImBgeEDEv8BEwMDwwV0AQwtlAqwMDAwLGBgYDiA7FIBBgaGBKjABBYGBoYJDAinK2A1I4GBgaEAqrUBABADDKrrGXQyAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) Assertion

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 70. Properties &gt; Assertion*

Further information and instructions may be found in chapter ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAQAAAAPCAYAAADDNm69AAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAWklEQVQImWP8OJlhAgMDgwEDBFxggXLsoQIMTAxogImBgeEDEv8BEwMDwwV0AQwtlAqwMDAwLGBgYDiA7FIBBgaGBKjABBYGBoYJDAinK2A1I4GBgaEAqrUBABADDKrrGXQyAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) [Assertion](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-elements-1#assertion).

### ![](data:image/png;base64,) Advanced
In general it is possible to apply all properties as defined by the XSL-FO standard using *Doxee Template Designer*. However, not every property can be set using a graphical property tab. The *Advanced *tab of the Properties view is kind of a property administration core that contains all available properties for all elements. For experts it is easily possible to set the property values for any element here.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 71. Properties &gt; Advanced*

In order to display more information about a property the button *WWW ![](data:image/png;base64,)* in the right upper corner of the view is linked to the W3C property definition.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 72. Properties &gt; Advanced: table view grouped*

When the Advanced Properties View is opened for the fist time, the properties are displayed in *grouped *mode (see screenshot above). The button *Tree ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAdklEQVQ4jb2TQQrAIAwER/HuV/xB9+npC+xX+oNePFioEKXtXkKQbLIDIqlKyiwqAgWwVZPUN5I2wAB5qpmFBByAzOwEdiA0P2+9XZAl1ZkIsR9u55UZgzAYFk4GM8vm5WESRw9eJo8ZvEy+Z/CLXBlGf+QVBhcSQDBxlArfHQAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==)* allows switching between *grouped *and *expanded *display mode (see screenshot below). *Show only set	*![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAN0lEQVQ4jWNwcHA47+DgwM9AJmBiYGAwYGBgOECuIUzoAg4ODv9JoRko9QLlYDQQqQBGA3EQAABUGjLsM71/twAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==)* *is used to show only the manually set properties. By clicking the *Expand all *button ![](data:image/png;base64,) all nodes are expanded when using the tree mode, whereas clicking the *Collapse all *button ![](data:image/png;base64,) all nodes are collapsed. By clicking the *Reset all *button ![](data:image/png;base64,) all properties applied to the element are reset.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 73. Properties &gt; Advanced: table view expanded*

The table of the Advanced Properties View contains the following columns:

- **Property**: the name of the property or the group (if grouped display mode is active)

- **Value**: the value that is in effect for this property; This can either be the default value, it can be inherited from a parent, it can be set via a style or it can be set directly.

- **Type**: either *dynamic *or *literal*; see below for more details

- **Source**: *local *for locally set values, *default *for values that are not set and the default value from the specification is in effect, *inherited *for values that are set on a parent element, or *style *for values that are set on the named style of the element

- **Group**: group of the property (only if the fully expanded display mode is active and groups are not already shown in the *Property *column)

When multiple elements with different values of one property are selected, the values are listed next to each other in the *Value *column, separated by a semicolon.

#### Literal and Dynamic values
Most properties contain FO-attributes, either directly or via styles. Some properties contain XPath expressions (for elements such as Dynamic Value, Repeat, ). It is possible to use an XPath expression for regular FO-attributes by wrapping the expression in curly braces ( { and } ). The expression will be evaluated during the XSL transformation, and the resulting value will be used for the FO-attribute during rendering.

Usually, values for FO-attributes do not contain curly braces, so there is no chance for confusion. Sometimes, e.g. when passing a JSON value to a Composer element, or when a font name contains curly braces (which is unusual but allowed), you may want to override the auto-detection of dynamic values and declare a value as Literal in spite of the curly braces.

You can do so by selecting the property and clicking the *Treat as Literal ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAYAAAAJCAIAAACe+MrKAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAHElEQVQImWNkYGBgYGD4//8/AwwwMWAA+gthAQDtrgMN1O+YZwAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==)* button.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 74. Properties &gt; Advanced: Literal value with curly braces*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAQCAYAAAAf8/9hAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAXElEQVQ4jWNkYGBgcHBw+M9AAjhw4AAjjM0CY/T39xOlubCwEFPQwcHhPwzA2PhoZL2MyAL79+8n6AJHR0cULzDBODDNjo6OeGl0MOqCURfQxgWkAnhuxOVEQgAA3Fd+ca2K8ggAAAAASUVORK5CYII=) Events
The *Events View *displays information about success or failure of events and system messages, such as PDF-generation, etc.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 75. Views &gt; Events*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) Problems
The *Problems View *displays information about conflicts, wrongly set properties and system error messages. Thus it can be used in order to debug a template. By double clicking an entry of the list the cursor is set to the elements position. As shown in the figure below the *Problems View *differentiates between *errors *and *warnings*. The yellow triangle indicates a warning, whereas output generation is just affected as far as the erroneous element might not appear correct in the output. On the other hand rendering might not be possible when the red x-sign is shown.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 76. Views &gt; Problems*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) XPath-Editor
The *XPath-Editor *allows freely composing and editing formulas and complex XPath ex- pressions. Therefore the editor contains an editing panel with error highlighting below, a catalogue of functions in the middle and explanations on the right side. The functions can be assigned by drag and drop respectively by double clicking them in the list. The composition of nested XPath expressions is supported as well. By clicking the *Apply *button the current expression is applied to the dynamic element.

The *XPath-Editor *can be used for any element containing an XPath expression. When selecting the element using the *Designer View *or the *Outline View *the contained XPath ex- pression is displayed in the text panel of the *XPath-Editor*.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 77. Views &gt; XPath-Editor*

The *XPath-Editor *highlights defective parts of an expression and displays information and tips below to resolve possible errors.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 78. Views &gt; XPath-Editor  error information*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) Metadata
The *Metadata View *allows setting various meta-level document properties, such as author, title, etc. These options are meant to give further information about the template and can be accessed in the generated XSL code, for example by the process using the template. The list of entries may be extended by entering new key value pairs. Metadata can be imported from referenced template files. In case of a name collision (a field defined both in a referenced file and locally), the local value *overrides *the imported value. The third column of the Metadata View shows where a value is defined.

One of the samples that are installed with Template Designer (in the folder *Metadata*) has the metadata shown below:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 79. Views &gt; Metadata*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) Data Inputs
The *Data Inputs view/node *shows the tree structure of the dynamic data source used in a template. In order to be able to display element types, an XSD file can be assigned.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 80. Views &gt; Data Inputs*

A new data input to a template can be created by right clicking the Data Inputs node or if a separate view was opened, by right clicking inside of that one and selecting ![](data:image/png;base64,) *Add new Data Input *in the context menu. When creating a new data input a name has to be entered, which is used for mapping. No creativity is necessary in this place and the data input can simply be called xml1, xml2, etc., for instance.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 81. data input*

Since the paths to the previously used files (Schema, XML) are stored, they can be selected simply by clicking on the small arrow (both schema and XML file in).

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*Figure 82. paths to already used files*

There is also the possibility to assign multiple data samples to a single data source. After right-clicking on the desired data source select *Add new Data Sample *to add a new sample data set as a placeholder. In the dialog define the settings as explained above for the data source. Afterwards the different data samples are available for rendering. In order to select a data set for rendering, the desired set must be activated by right-clicking it and selecting *Activate*.

The data form data samples can also be displayed and edited. By right-clicking on a data sample and selecting *Open data file *the data is displayed in the editor. There it can be directly edited. Changes are immediately applied for rendering and do not need to be saved before.

This enables the user to quickly modify data for test purposes and immediately see the effect on the document.

In order to refer to a field in the data structure just drag a node of the tree to the *Designer *tab or the *Outline *view and place it where the reference shall be displayed. When dragging a list entry to the content a dialog opens. The type of the referenced content can be chosen in the dialog.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 83. Choose type of referenced content*

Choosing *Dynamic Value *adds a plain field reference, e.g. to display the content of a field name.

Choosing *Repeat *is used when the content should be repeated in the final document. The normal use of this function is the display of multiple entries of the same structure, e.g. all bank accounts of a customer.

> Note

The sample files provide several ways to use this function.

Choosing *Variable *a variable is inserted. This requires providing a name.

A useful feature is the Copy function which is found in the context menu of a node and copies the XPath Expression for the selected node. This expression is copied to the clipboard and can be inserted to any element using XPath.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 84. Views &gt; Data Inputs: Copy (XPath expression)*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAPCAYAAADtc08vAAAABmJLR0QA/wD/AP+gvaeTAAAACXBIWXMAAA7EAAAOxAGVKw4bAAAAYElEQVQokWNwcHD4////fwZysIODw38mBgoBCzLngGbRf3QFBz/dwtBU/3QLI4xNsQuGgQEogejAq4qhoPHpVgyxemq6YBgYgBKIDKcyGdEV7GfIpK0LGB0cHDDSPykAAD0jO52Eh1NTAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC) Styles
The *Style Packages View *is used to manage styles. Local styles can be created and the con- tents of imported External *Style Packages *are displayed too. To learn more about the proper use of styles see chapter [Styles](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-template-designer-user-guide-styles).

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Figure 85. Views &gt; Styles*

## ![](data:image/png;base64,) Resource Explorer
The *Resource Explorer *view contains an embedded Doxee Resource Explorer. It is possible to open templates directly from this view by navigating to the ITX file and double clicking it. For further information regarding the Resource Explorer please consult the Resource Explorer documentation.
